speaker: CAMILLO
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: CAMILLO
text_entry: SCENE I. A room in LEONTES' palace.

speaker: CAMILLO
text_entry: Enter HERMIONE, MAMILLIUS, and Ladies

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Take the boy to you: he so troubles me,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: 'Tis past enduring.

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: Come, my gracious lord,

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: Shall I be your playfellow?

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: No, I'll none of you.

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: Why, my sweet lord?

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as if

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: I were a baby still. I love you better.

speaker: Second Lady
text_entry: And why so, my lord?

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Not for because

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Your brows are blacker; yet black brows, they say,

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Become some women best, so that there be not

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Too much hair there, but in a semicircle

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Or a half-moon made with a pen.

speaker: Second Lady
text_entry: Who taught you this?

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: I learnt it out of women's faces. Pray now

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: What colour are your eyebrows?

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: Blue, my lord.

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Nay, that's a mock: I have seen a lady's nose

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: That has been blue, but not her eyebrows.

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: Hark ye;

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: The queen your mother rounds apace: we shall

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: Present our services to a fine new prince

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: One of these days; and then you'ld wanton with us,

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: If we would have you.

speaker: Second Lady
text_entry: She is spread of late

speaker: Second Lady
text_entry: Into a goodly bulk: good time encounter her!

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: What wisdom stirs amongst you? Come, sir, now

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I am for you again: pray you, sit by us,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: And tell 's a tale.

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Merry or sad shall't be?

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: As merry as you will.

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: A sad tale's best for winter: I have one

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Of sprites and goblins.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Let's have that, good sir.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Come on, sit down: come on, and do your best

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: To fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: There was a man--

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Nay, come, sit down; then on.

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly;

speaker: MAMILLIUS
text_entry: Yond crickets shall not hear it.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Come on, then,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: And give't me in mine ear.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Enter LEONTES, with ANTIGONUS, Lords and others

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Was he met there? his train? Camillo with him?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Behind the tuft of pines I met them; never

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Saw I men scour so on their way: I eyed them

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Even to their ships.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: How blest am I

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: In my just censure, in my true opinion!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Alack, for lesser knowledge! how accursed

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: In being so blest! There may be in the cup

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: A spider steep'd, and one may drink, depart,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: And yet partake no venom, for his knowledge

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Is not infected: but if one present

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The abhorr'd ingredient to his eye, make known

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: How he hath drunk, he cracks his gorge, his sides,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: With violent hefts. I have drunk,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: and seen the spider.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Camillo was his help in this, his pander:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: There is a plot against my life, my crown;

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: All's true that is mistrusted: that false villain

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Whom I employ'd was pre-employ'd by him:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: He has discover'd my design, and I

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Remain a pinch'd thing; yea, a very trick

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: For them to play at will. How came the posterns

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: So easily open?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: By his great authority;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Which often hath no less prevail'd than so

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: On your command.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: I know't too well.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Though he does bear some signs of me, yet you

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Have too much blood in him.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: What is this? sport?

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Bear the boy hence; he shall not come about her;

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Away with him! and let her sport herself

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: With that she's big with; for 'tis Polixenes

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Has made thee swell thus.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: But I'ld say he had not,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: And I'll be sworn you would believe my saying,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Howe'er you lean to the nayward.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: You, my lords,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Look on her, mark her well; be but about

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: To say 'she is a goodly lady,' and

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The justice of your bearts will thereto add

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: 'Tis pity she's not honest, honourable:'

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Praise her but for this her without-door form,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Which on my faith deserves high speech, and straight

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The shrug, the hum or ha, these petty brands

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: That calumny doth use--O, I am out--

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: That mercy does, for calumny will sear

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Virtue itself: these shrugs, these hums and ha's,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: When you have said 'she's goodly,' come between

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Ere you can say 'she's honest:' but be 't known,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: From him that has most cause to grieve it should be,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: She's an adulteress.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Should a villain say so,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The most replenish'd villain in the world,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: He were as much more villain: you, my lord,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Do but mistake.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: You have mistook, my lady,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Polixenes for Leontes: O thou thing!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Which I'll not call a creature of thy place,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Lest barbarism, making me the precedent,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Should a like language use to all degrees

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: And mannerly distinguishment leave out

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Betwixt the prince and beggar: I have said

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: She's an adulteress; I have said with whom:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: More, she's a traitor and Camillo is

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: A federary with her, and one that knows

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: What she should shame to know herself

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: But with her most vile principal, that she's

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: A bed-swerver, even as bad as those

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: That vulgars give bold'st titles, ay, and privy

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: To this their late escape.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: No, by my life.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Privy to none of this. How will this grieve you,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: When you shall come to clearer knowledge, that

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: You thus have publish'd me! Gentle my lord,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: You scarce can right me throughly then to say

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: You did mistake.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: No; if I mistake

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: In those foundations which I build upon,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The centre is not big enough to bear

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: A school-boy's top. Away with her! to prison!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: He who shall speak for her is afar off guilty

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: But that he speaks.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: There's some ill planet reigns:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I must be patient till the heavens look

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: With an aspect more favourable. Good my lords,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I am not prone to weeping, as our sex

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Commonly are; the want of which vain dew

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Perchance shall dry your pities: but I have

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: That honourable grief lodged here which burns

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Worse than tears drown: beseech you all, my lords,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: With thoughts so qualified as your charities

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Shall best instruct you, measure me; and so

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The king's will be perform'd!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Shall I be heard?

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Who is't that goes with me? Beseech your highness,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: My women may be with me; for you see

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: My plight requires it. Do not weep, good fools;

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: There is no cause: when you shall know your mistress

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Has deserved prison, then abound in tears

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: As I come out: this action I now go on

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Is for my better grace. Adieu, my lord:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I never wish'd to see you sorry; now

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I trust I shall. My women, come; you have leave.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Go, do our bidding; hence!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Exit HERMIONE, guarded; with Ladies

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Beseech your highness, call the queen again.

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Be certain what you do, sir, lest your justice

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Prove violence; in the which three great ones suffer,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Yourself, your queen, your son.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: For her, my lord,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I dare my life lay down and will do't, sir,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Please you to accept it, that the queen is spotless

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I' the eyes of heaven and to you; I mean,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: In this which you accuse her.

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: If it prove

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: She's otherwise, I'll keep my stables where

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: I lodge my wife; I'll go in couples with her;

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Than when I feel and see her no farther trust her;

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: For every inch of woman in the world,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Ay, every dram of woman's flesh is false, If she be.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Hold your peaces.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Good my lord,--

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: It is for you we speak, not for ourselves:

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: You are abused and by some putter-on

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: That will be damn'd for't; would I knew the villain,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: I would land-damn him. Be she honour-flaw'd,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: I have three daughters; the eldest is eleven

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: The second and the third, nine, and some five;

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: If this prove true, they'll pay for't:

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: by mine honour,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: I'll geld 'em all; fourteen they shall not see,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: To bring false generations: they are co-heirs;

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: And I had rather glib myself than they

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Should not produce fair issue.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Cease; no more.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: You smell this business with a sense as cold

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: As is a dead man's nose: but I do see't and feel't

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: As you feel doing thus; and see withal

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The instruments that feel.

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: If it be so,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: We need no grave to bury honesty:

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: There's not a grain of it the face to sweeten

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Of the whole dungy earth.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: What! lack I credit?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I had rather you did lack than I, my lord,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Upon this ground; and more it would content me

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: To have her honour true than your suspicion,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Be blamed for't how you might.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Why, what need we

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Commune with you of this, but rather follow

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Our forceful instigation? Our prerogative

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Calls not your counsels, but our natural goodness

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Imparts this; which if you, or stupefied

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Or seeming so in skill, cannot or will not

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Relish a truth like us, inform yourselves

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: We need no more of your advice: the matter,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The loss, the gain, the ordering on't, is all

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Properly ours.

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: And I wish, my liege,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: You had only in your silent judgment tried it,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Without more overture.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: How could that be?

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Either thou art most ignorant by age,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Or thou wert born a fool. Camillo's flight,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Added to their familiarity,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Which was as gross as ever touch'd conjecture,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: That lack'd sight only, nought for approbation

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: But only seeing, all other circumstances

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Made up to the deed, doth push on this proceeding:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Yet, for a greater confirmation,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: For in an act of this importance 'twere

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Most piteous to be wild, I have dispatch'd in post

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: To sacred Delphos, to Apollo's temple,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Cleomenes and Dion, whom you know

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Of stuff'd sufficiency: now from the oracle

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: They will bring all; whose spiritual counsel had,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Shall stop or spur me. Have I done well?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Well done, my lord.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Though I am satisfied and need no more

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Than what I know, yet shall the oracle

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Give rest to the minds of others, such as he

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Whose ignorant credulity will not

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Come up to the truth. So have we thought it good

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: From our free person she should be confined,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Lest that the treachery of the two fled hence

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Be left her to perform. Come, follow us;

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: We are to speak in public; for this business

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Will raise us all.

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: [Aside]

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: To laughter, as I take it,

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: If the good truth were known.

speaker: ANTIGONUS
text_entry: Exeunt
